Description: Fragment of rim and upper body (mended from three) of large East Greek (possibly Aeolian) Grey Ware pottery open vessel, possibly a deep bowl or krater; carinated shoulder and everted rim with slight, flattened top; light grey fabric with large quantity of limestone and some mica inclusions; very worn dark grey slip; incised decoration consisting of two pairs of double wavy lines in shoulder zone, which also has some shallow grooving.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, "Qasr", East Annexe (C), chamber 19 ? (?)
Curator's comments: A possible provenance from Tell Dafana is to be considered because of the pencilled mark '19' on one of the sherds. Incised wavy lines are reminiscent of similar patterns found on grey wares from Troy, see Blegen, ‘Troy: Excavations conducted by the University of Cincinnati 1932-38’, IV (1958), and from Lesbos, see Lamb, JHS 52 (1932) 1-12. See also British Museum 1965,0930.508.
The shape is otherwise unattested at Naukratis, though has near parallels in sherds from Tell Dafana in the set British Museum 1888,0208.139.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GL.031)
